metadata.case_name: State of Bombay v. Jagmohandas Masruwala

facts.text: Ms. Jagmohandas Masruwala, a registered dealer under the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946, filed Original Suit No. 10 of 1956 against the State of Bombay for recovery of Rs. 31,852/8/3 paid as advance sales-tax on various dates when submitting returns for the period January 26, 1950 to March 31, 1951, and interest thereon at 4%, viz., Rs. 3,998.
The amount was paid as advance tax in respect of sale of goods effected outside the State of Bombay, which were taxable under the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946.
The Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946 became void by virtue of Art. 286(1)(a) of the Constitution on January 26, 1950.
The mistake was discovered when the Governor of Bombay promulgated Bombay Ordinance No. 2 of 1952.
No assessment has been made under the Act, and the plaintiff has not called into question any assessment or order made under the Act.

The Second Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division, Surat, held the suit not barred under ss. 13 and 20 of the 1946 Act and ss. 19 and 29 of the 1952 Act, and within limitation; decreed Rs. 35,850/8/3 with future interest and costs.
Bombay High Court in First Appeals Nos. 44 and 45 of 1959 affirmed the decree but omitted interest as damages; judgments dated March 25/26, 1960.
Sales were in respect of goods consigned to purchasers outside the State of Bombay and for consumption outside the State; apparently covered by Art. 286(1)(a) before amendment.
Both courts below found that the plaintiff came to know of the mistake on December 22, 1952, the date of the promulgation of the Governor's ordinance.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was barred expressly by s. 20 or impliedly by s. 13 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946 (or corresponding sections in 1952 Act).
Whether the suit was barred by limitation under Art. 96 of the Limitation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The suit was barred by ss. 13 and 20 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946, and ss. 19 and 29 of the Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1952.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 13, 20 Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946; ss. 19, 29 Bombay Sales Tax Act 1952; Raleigh Investment Co. Ltd. v. Governor-General in Council

petitioner_arguments.text: The suit was barred by limitation.
Filing return and paying tax amounts to self-assessment, bringing it within s. 20.
S. 13 impliedly bars the suit as it provides machinery for refund after assessment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 13 Bombay Sales Tax Act 1946; Kamala Mills case

respondent_arguments.text: The Act became void by Art. 286(1)(a) on January 26, 1950; amount paid under mistake of law.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(1)(a) Constitution; State of Tripura v. Province of East Bengal

respondent_arguments.text: Suit within limitation as mistake known on Dec 22, 1952.
Section similar to s. 13 existed in Bengal Agricultural Income Tax Act in Tripura case.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Tripura v. Province of East Bengal

court_reasoning.text: S. 20 does not expressly bar the suit as no assessment made and suit does not question any assessment; covered by Tripura case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'assessment' in s. 20 refers to assessments under ss. 11 and 11A.

court_reasoning.text: S. 13 does not impliedly bar; provides refund after assessment order, no machinery for constitutional invalidity objections; sales tax authorities not competent for ultra vires questions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dealer cannot apply under s. 13 till assessment order passed.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 96 Limitation Act applies; concurrent finding that mistake known on Dec 22, 1952 not disturbed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suit filed within 3 years from knowledge of mistake.

court_reasoning.text: Shah J. concurs on bar and limitation but notes sales tax authorities could entertain objection on Art. 286 interpretation, though stage not reached here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Question of jurisdiction is interpretation issue per Kamala Mills.

holdings.text: Suit not barred expressly by s. 20 or impliedly by s. 13 of Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946.
Suit not barred by limitation under Art. 96.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raleigh Investment Co. Ltd. v. Governor-General in Council
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions similar to s. 20 but not applicable as no assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Tripura v. Province of East Bengal
Kamala Mills Ltd. v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Not inconsistent with Tripura; aware of machinery but gave effect to plain words.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. S. Venkataraman v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales tax authorities not competent for ultra vires questions.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Kerala v. Aluminium Industries Ltd.
United Motors India Ltd. v. State of Bombay

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Does not bar suit for refund of advance tax paid under mistake before assessment; s.13 for post-assessment refunds only.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Replacement provisions; do not bar suit.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Rendered Act void for inter-state sales from Jan 26, 1950.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Three years from date mistake known to plaintiff.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed; High Court decree affirmed holding suit maintainable and within limitation; no bar under sales tax provisions.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for principal sum with future interest from suit date and costs.
outcome.costs: Appeals dismissed with costs. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: We are unable to read the word assessment in S. 20 to include a mere filing of return and payment by a registered dealer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects self-assessment argument for barring suit.

key_quotes.text: S. 13 does not contemplate objections being entertained regarding the constitutional validity of any payment made by the dealer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No implied bar as no machinery for constitutional challenges.

key_quotes.text: Art. 96 applies to suits like the present.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms limitation from knowledge of mistake.
